clinical_study.brief_title: Lateral Episiotomy or Not in Vacuum Assisted Delivery in Primiparae
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial of Lateral Episiotomy Versus no Episiotomy in Vacuum or Forceps Assisted Delivery in Primiparae

brief_summary.textblock: Primiparae with a live singleton pregnancy in cephalic presentation past 34 gestational weeks will be randomized to lateral episiotomy or no episiotomy when operative vaginal delivery is indicated. Primary outcome is obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS) of any degree.

detailed_description.textblock:
Women giving birth at Danderyd Hospital will be included. Danderyd Hospital is a large teaching hospital affiliated to the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, Sweden. Danderyd Hospital attends approximately 6 000 deliveries annually, of which 300 are vacuum extractions in primiparae. Other hospitals in Stockholm County and other parts of Sweden will also be invited to participate in the study.
Lateral episiotomy will be performed according to the intervention description. Total sample size has been calculated to 700 women, if a reduction in sphincter tear frequency from today's 14.6% to 7.3% in operative vaginal deliveries is to be detected (estimated drop-out rate 30%). The women will be recruited over a maximum of 48 months. An interim analysis will be performed after 120 randomized women to each arm, since a reduction to less than 5% sphincter tears could be detected with less than 5% risk of a type-1 error at this sample size. If such a large reduction is seen, the study will be closed.
Data will be collected prospectively through Case Record Forms and the obstetrical medical file Obstetrix (Cerner Sverige AB), which covers approximately 98% of deliveries with complete data, and the Swedish Pregnancy Register covering the whole of Sweden from 2015 as well as the (optional) Swedish Obstetrical Tear Register, which Danderyd Hospital is a part of since 2014. From the Obstetrical Tear Registry, questionnaires are sent out in paper form or electronically to patients with a diagnosed anal sphincter tear at delivery, 8 weeks and 12 months after delivery. The same questionnaires will be used in the follow-up of the study participants regardless of randomization or result (sphincter tear or not). In addition, the participants will be sent questionnaires regarding birth satisfaction at 8 weeks after delivery.

primary_outcome.description: Rupture or tear of the external and/or internal anal sphincter at any degree (third and fourth degree perineal tear); International Classification of Diseases (ICD)-10 O70.2 or O70.3.

secondary_outcome.measure: Second degree perineal or vaginal tear
secondary_outcome.description: Rupture, tear or hematoma in the perineum or vagina; International Classification of Diseases (ICD)-10 O70.1, O70.9, O71.4-9.
Questionnaire at 8 weeks after delivery through the Swedish Obstetrical Tear Registry regarding number of days using analgetic medication.
Questionnaire at 8 weeks and 1 year after delivery through the Swedish Obstetrical Tear Registry regarding anal continence function (Wexner score based).
Questionnaire at 1 year after delivery through the Swedish Obstetrical Tear Registry regarding sexual function.
Questionnaire at 8 weeks after delivery regarding patient satisfaction using the Birth Satisfaction Scale short form.
Estimated blood loss in milliliters through weighing of sheets and drapes during and up to 6 hours after delivery.
Frequncy of scalp injury to the neonate after instrumental delivery, such as open wounds, cephalic hematoma, subgaleal hematoma, and intracranial hemorrhage, according to diagnose by neonatologist.
Questionnaire at 1 year after delivery through the Swedish Obstetrical Tear Registry regarding symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.

arm_group.description: Lateral episiotomy (left or right) is performed by the attending physician at the crowning of the fetal head in operative vaginal delivery by vacuum extraction (or forceps, rare). Regular manual perineal support is applied.
No episiotomy is performed during operative vaginal delivery. The woman is allowed to tear naturally. Regular manual perineal support is applied.

intervention.description: When the woman is randomized to episiotomy, lateral episiotomy is performed with scissors on the left or right side of the vaginal opening. Origin of incision is 1.0 - 2.0 cm from the midline/posterior forchette and is cut 3.0 cm or more towards the ischial tuberosity at an angle of 45-60 degrees from the midline.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Primiparae 18 years old or more, able to give a written informed consent in Swedish, with a live singleton pregnancy, in a cephalic presentation over 34 completed gestational weeks with a medical indication of operative vaginal delivery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous vaginal or perineal surgery for anomalies, prolapse or incontinence, previous female circumcision, any contra-indication to operative vaginal delivery (ie fetal disorder or malformation).
